segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Hello, all. First of all, thank you very much for coming down to my talk. I know it's early
morning and we had some really good party yesterday evening, so I wasn't expecting a
lot of audience, honestly. Well, the topic I'll be delivering talk upon today is core
channels in IEEE 2.11 standards, or for that matter, regular Wi-Fi standards. So how I
actually did reach to this theme of research, or for that matter, theme of finding something.
I can't call it as research for that matter because it may be available by many people,
may be received by many people already. The thing was, I was doing a lot of consulting
work, I was doing a lot of testing, both, sometimes red teaming, sometimes blue teaming.
There, I used to consult with majority of my clients saying, okay, this is loophole in your
network, this is how you're supposed to patch it and all. But then, at the back of my mind,
there was something else going on. Why am I always supposed to, you know, face the attack,
or then mitigate the attack? Can there be some other way out so that we cannot actually be
available, or a victim will not be available for an attacker at all, at least in case of wireless
networks? So yes, so I was thinking on that particular lines, can we do something regarding
this situation? Meanwhile, one of my paper on wireless got declined in positive hack days,
and I consider that as one of very positive setback ever. Now, this is kind of contradictory
statement I'm making positive and setback, because, setback because obvious, declined,
nobody likes decline of a paper as such. Positive it was because that review gave me a lot of ideas
about how can I actually explore this area in little more detail. They had very specific set
of questions. Why exactly you're trying to do this all on application layer? Why not on some
other layers in your ISO-OSI model? There is where I came to know, I mean, there is where I
actually striked with one more idea where we know, in case of wireless networks, that is,
IEEE 802.11, and in case of wired networks, that is, most of the times IEEE 802.3, we have
difference on physical layer and data link layer. Rest of the layers are same. Considering the size
of one frame, a very average frame, in case of wired network, it is around, say, 12 bytes or
16 bytes, somewhere around that. I may be wrong in figures, but this is somewhere near to that,
right? Same thing about wireless networks. It's somewhere around 200 plus bytes, just in case,
if we happen to exploit certain behavioral traits of wireless network frames, IEEE 802.11 frames.
So, that is how both of these combinations clubbed well, and then we've started learning
up, learning about it. Yes, there was one more thing that happened. I was initially working on
Avel side, sorry, client-side Avel twin detection in case of wireless. Again, there was same
question. Why am I supposed to face attack? Can I not simply avoid that attack all the way? So,
these all boiled down to my some exploration in code channels in wireless. So, initially,
my state of mind was like this, honestly. I was reading, reading, reading. I have been reading
almost like few hundred pages per day into that IEEE 802.11 standard, which is like 6,000 pages
big and everything. That was a lot of clutter, but slowly, when I started concentrating on
things repetitively, things started getting sorted. So, yes, that is how I came to know
about few facts about wireless networks, which have never been documented. So, there are always
pieces of story you see, which have never been described in theory. Purposely, those things are
kept from disclosing. There would be operational limitations, or there would be something else
that is basically defeating the motive of that standard. That's the reason they could not,
or would not have been able to include that into the documentation per se.
And for such all things, even IEEE 802.11 standards is not an exception as well.
So, some basics. I assume that some of us may not be much aware of what exactly happens in case of
wireless networks. So, I'm giving a very, very brief introduction for what exactly is access
point. If you see the animation at the center, there is some circle that's access point,
which is basically making available a network, or for that matter, network connectivity to
host in the local radio periphery. And if you see that WNIC, I understand the image is a little
blurred, but please spare me for that. So, that WNIC is nothing but the receivers, which are
actually availing wireless networks from that access point per se. So, back to the basics again.
So, what exactly is IEEE blamed for? Many of us know IEEE 802.11 has been targeted since 1998. If
I'm not wrong, there have been a lot of attacks, different types of attacks, variety of attacks,
like authorization or deauth, and then there was WEP crack. I mean, on privacy, on connectivity,
every type of attack, I mean, on every type of aspect, majority of attacks have been so far done.
So, is that kind of a loose link in client security? Obviously, yes,
because rogue access points poses a lot of threat. Eavesdropping, yes, another issue.
So, victims, who all are victims? Now, let me edit this thing with a little bit of IoT devices as
well, plus mobiles, cameras, printers, gaming consoles, laptops, desktops, and all your
medical devices and whatnot. So, they all are available for exploitation per se.
So, some basics again on modes. So, in case of wireless networks, we have certain modes
assigned to the devices we use, or rather there are more than around 14 modes on which the device
can be operated according to the document. I'm using just four of them, because one of these
four would be of interest of us. So, managed mode is nothing but a station, which could be a host,
could be a host, or could be your access point in certain cases. So, this could be your
example of host, a managed host, we can say. And then ad hoc, where you basically try to
edit the protocol stack, and then you try to use that protocol stack, which is not
thoroughly abiding by IEEE 2.11 standards, but working almost like 90%
to the functionality which is present into the IEEE 2.11 standards. So, that is nothing but your
ad hoc station mode. Then there is master mode, which is like access point, and then there are
monitor mode. Now, this is the mode which we would be using in most of the experimentation here.
So, monitor mode basically gives your station or your wireless network interface card a
capability to basically sniff all the traffic which is directed or non-directed to that
particular host, as well allows you injecting any type of traffic, which again is not meant
for that particular network, or maybe meant for that network. So, some bookish definition,
code channel is a type of security attack that creates a capability to transfer information,
objects between processes that are not supposed to be allowed to communicate by the computer
security policy. So, there have always been a way to basically smuggle data over many frames,
for that matter, because, oh yes, before going further, our concentration of discussion here
would be on data link layer, that too specifically on broadcast frames. I'll come to that point,
like why exactly broadcast frames? So, we have been focusing on some aspects of data link layer,
and that too specifically on beacons and probes. Yes, this attack, I mean, we can run these type
of code channels on almost any frame, provided we have certain connectivity established,
but in case of probes, beacons and probes, we don't even need that.
So, some basic types, management frames, control frames, and data frames, we are interested only
in management frames. And that too, for our discussion, we would be considering probe
request, probe response, and beacon. For this whole experimentation, we have used
SCPI as an instrument, which actually allowed us manipulating packet, forging or crafting packet as
well. So, that actually allowed us crafting a packet, which was not according to the standard,
but still it allowed me crafting that packet and allowed me injecting that packet as well.
So, how we can basically craft a frame in SCPI? So, there are like these four layers we use.
So, radio tap, .11, .11 beacon, slash .11 probe request, either of one you want to select,
and then .11 ELT. .11 ELT actually stands for information element. This is where we are trying
to ship our data over. So, for those who are interested in little more theory, this is basic
structure of beacon frame. So, what exactly is a beacon frame? Beacon frame is nothing but that
advertisement frame, which has been propagated by an access point to convey its presence into
the local radio periphery. So, that is how our devices come to know, here we have that particular
network PPNT something. So, how our devices come to know that, okay, this particular wireless
network is present in the local radio periphery, it is through that beacon frame, which has been
emitted by that wireless network having SSID PPNT or something. Let me see if we can.
So, these all are wireless networks, and these basically these names are nothing but SSID,
service set identifiers. So, having said this, beacon frame does not require you to authenticate
with any host or any other device, which is accepting or understanding a particular frame,
does not even require to have a connectivity established earlier,
and that is the reason we have chosen this particular frame.
And again, this is broadcast. So, we do not need to worry about the volume of frames,
which are available into the local radio periphery. You understand,
we need to be a little more deeper. So, this is how we can basically craft
beacon frame per se into the into SCP. So, this one is kind of sorry.
So, this one actually specifies the radio tap layer telling
SCP that yes, we are using data link layer frame of IEEE 2.11 standard or for that matter radio
device, then dot 11 in that in bracket address 1, which is nothing but your destination address.
Here we are supposed to put that is destination MAC address, which is all F means we are
broadcasting the frame. Address 2 is nothing but BSSID, address 3 as well is a BSSID.
Now, this dot 11 beacon, this actually allows you giving capability of beacon to the particular
frame or for that particular wireless frame we can say. So, here we have mentioned the
capability, which actually is nothing but set of certain hardware information or certain hardware
capabilities here and then the comes the real stuff that is dot 11 ELT, which is nothing but
information elements. So, ID 0 represents SSID and it is basically kind of key value pair we can say
where we have ID 0 and then value for that ID is nothing but info and the info is nothing but
demo, demo, demo. So, here the service set identifier for this beacon frame would be demo,
demo, demo. So, this is repetitive, fine. So, there could be lot of information stuffed inside
such frames. So, that example we can see live as well and we will be seeing that soon.
So, how can we go ahead with that? Edit the fields, which have better lens in order to ship

country, etcetera. Well, I have actually got this list of elements from again IEEE 802 dot 11

I have got that page available made for you.
So, it is basically here element ID and then the length of indicated elements.
So, element ID we are supposed to show in that particular dot 11 ELT format where ID is supposed
to be 67 for that matter and length could be anything between 4 to 28 octet for that matter.
So, that is how you can craft a frame. So, obviously I wanted to ship more data. So, I chose
little bigger length fields here. So, again the same question I think we have answered this thing.
Beacon probe frames does not require auth or association to themselves being broadcast. So,
no need to zero down on host selection reduces the pain a little bit. So, this could be more
of a broadcast attack. We are not pinpointing on a specific user per se. Presence of these frames
in multitude in local wireless periphery is a common phenomena. So, there would not be any
suspicion raised just because there are like some hundreds of beacon frames available for specific
SSID. Again the multitude will always facilitate the larger chunk of the data to ship. Yes,
that is another possibility. Some fields allow pushing more than 250 bytes of data in a single
frame. So, initially I was trying to stuff 250 bytes into one particular field which was not
some way practical. It was taking somewhere around 208 bytes or something like that, but then same
time we can use multiple elements IDs to club a lot of data into it and can send it over.
For this experimentation we have tested text data. We have not tested something else apart
from that. So, 250 bytes are quite enough for malicious payload if you have seen shellcode.
They usually come like 50 bytes, 90 bytes or something like that.
So, some representative example here. We have used a traffic indication map as one of the
fields where we can stuff the data. So, partial virtual bitmap field into the traffic indication
map actually allows you shipping around 250 bytes of data. At early stages it was easy,
really easy to fabricate as I was struggling a lot with KPE as well as trying to understand
